definitions.definition: Something assumed without proof as being self-evident or generally accepted, especially when used as a basis for an argument. Sometimes distinguished from axioms as being relevant to a particular science or context, rather than universally true, and following from other axioms rather than being an absolute assumption.
A fundamental element; a basic principle.
To assume as a truthful or accurate premise or axiom, especially as a basis of an argument.
To appoint or request one's appointment to an ecclesiastical office.
To request, demand or claim for oneself.
